awd_abstract_narration:
In this award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division, Dr. Igor Lednev, from the University at Albany, SUNY, New York, will study the mechanism of refolding of fibrils, which are protein aggregates with a common cross-beta sheet structure. It is well accepted that fibrils are extraordinarily stable and are the most energetically favorable forms of proteins.

The main objectives of the proposed research are: (i) to establish the kinetic mechanism of spontaneous refolding of apo-alpha-lactalbumin fibrils by a combination of modern spectroscopic techniques, including deep ultraviolet Raman spectroscopy, intrinsic fluorescence, atomic force microscopy, and scanning transmission electron microscopy, with advanced statistical analyses, such as chemometrics and 2D correlation spectroscopy, and (ii) to create a comprehensive map of the accessible pathways of the refolding process by varying the solution temperature, salinity and pH.

The spontaneous refolding of fibrils is relevant to disease, but, more importantly, it is fundamentally significant for biology in general.  Understanding the mechanism of this process could allow control of the biological activity of fibrils.  

The proposed program trains both graduate and undergraduate students in advanced methods and techniques. This cross-disciplinary project engages students in biophysics, biochemistry and molecular biology, and provides future professional scientists and engineers with a range of important technical skills. Undergraduate and graduate students from historically underrepresented groups (African-American and Latino students) will be engaged in studies related to the proposed work. Research results acquired through this award will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses, including Analytical Chemistry, Instrumental Analysis and Theory and Techniques of Biophysics and Biophysical Chemistry.

por.por_cntn:
There is increasing evidence that protein aggregation plays a vital role in a variety of biological processes.  Specific to this project, fibrillar aggregates, filamentous assemblies of peptides and proteins, have been found in a wide range of organisms, from bacteria to mammals, and have been shown to possess different physiological functions. Some fibrillar aggregates, known as amyloid fibrils, are striking components of multiple neurodegenerative diseases, and their appearance correlates with pathology.  It is well accepted that fibrils are extraordinarily stable and are the most energetically favorable form of proteins.  We have recently discovered that mild temperature and salinity variations result in spontaneous refolding of protein fibrils from one polymorphic form to another.  This discovery suggests the opportunity to control the biological activity and associated toxicity of protein fibrils. The latter motivated us to investigate the mechanism of the spontaneous refolding of fibrillar aggregates, determine how common this phenomenon is for various proteins and whether the aggregates could be manipulated at physiological conditions. We utilized several modern spectroscopic techniques and most advanced statistical analysis to establish the kinetic mechanism of spontaneous refolding of protein fibrils initiated by mild changes in solution temperature, salinity and pH. Fibrils prepared from several different proteins were shown to refold spontaneously under certain conditions demonstrating a general nature of this phenomenon.

Chirality plays important role in chemistry and biology. We discovered that the chiral supramolecular organization of protofibrils is the principal underlying cause of the morphological heterogeneity of mature fibrils. Remarkably, the change in solution pH by one unit only triggers rapid transformation of one supramolecular chiral polymorph of prion protein fibrils into another. We concluded that the deprotonation of Asp and Glu amino acid residues on the surface of fibrils due to the pH change is the underlying cause of the spontaneous refolding process.

The formation of small misfolded aggregates is a key process for growing protein fibrils. The investigation of these aggregates is complicated by their transient nature and relatively low concentration.  We utilized for the first time surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) to probe directly the nucleation stage of the fibril formation. We demonstrated that the amount of protein oligomers increased after the first hour of incubation and then slowly decreased with time. This study provides valuable new information about the time-dependent structural organization of insulin oligomers and demonstrates the power and potential of SERS for detection and structural characterization of biological specimens present at low concentrations.

This discovery opens new potential possibilities for hydrogen sul?de in vivo activity, which needs to be investigated. One interesting outcome of our study is that we can expect the formation of trisul?de bridges in proteins when garlic is consumed.

Individual fragments swell and are quickly transformed into unordered protein structures.
